channel.title: Introduction to Shiny
channel.description: Recent content on Introduction to Shiny

item.title: Reactive data
item.description: In this example we only use the filtered gapminder data in a single place - to plot the graph. For this reason we did the filtering within the renderPlot() function. Let’s add another output to the app; we’ll show which country is the richest displayed on the graph, and what its GDP per capita is. This means that we’ll be using the gapminder data filtered by year and country in two places; on the graph itself and in the logic where we work out what the richest country is.

Shiny Workshop div.sourceCode { overflow-x: auto; } table.sourceCode, tr.sourceCode, td.lineNumbers, td.sourceCode { margin: 0; padding: 0; vertical-align: baseline; border: none; } table.sourceCode { width: 100%; line-height: 100%; } td.lineNumbers { text-align: right; padding-right: 4px; padding-left: 4px; color: #aaaaaa; border-right: 1px solid #aaaaaa; } td.sourceCode { padding-left: 5px; } code span.kw { color: #007020; font-weight: bold; } /* Keyword */ code span.dt { color: #902000; } /* DataType */ code span.

item.title: About
item.description: This site is for the RSE 2018 conference workshop on Shiny. It is written by David Mawdsley, with help from Joshua Woodcock and Louise Lever, who are all Research Software Engineers at the University of Manchester. Thanks to Christopher Woods at the University of Bristol for his mentoring and comments. This site is written using Hugo, the learn theme, and hosted on github. The course materials (i.e. the R code, data and example solutions) are hosted in a separate repository.
